Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will describe the difference between Trinity House school and other registered reformatory schools in terms of: (a) provision for security; and (b) regime or method of care or treatment of the person committed there; and the arrangements if any, she has made to monitor and evaluate the operation of, and results achieved by, Trinity House as compared with other establishments.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: There are two certified reformatory schools: Scoil Ard Mhuire, Lusk, and Trinity House School, Lusk. Scoil Ard Mhuire is an “open” school. The containment of the boys is dependent on the supervision of the staff (care staff and teachers) and the co-operation of the boys themselves.

Trinity House is a “secure” school. Security is provided in the structure of the building as well as in the number of staff responsible for the supervision of the boys. In both Scoil Ard Mhuire and Trinity House boys are placed on a carefully planned programme of rehabilitation which is structured to meet the individual needs of each boy. It focuses especially on identifying the positive aspects of each boy's behaviour and builds on strengths. A number of models of treatment are used depending on the response of each boy. The general aim is to improve each boy's self image and to reintegrate him into society as soon as possible.

The operation of Trinity House is carefully monitored by the Board of Management on behalf of the Minister. The staff of the school includes a full time psychologist, part of whose duties is to research into the efficacy of the programme. As the school did not become fully operational until the latter half of 1983 insufficient data is available as yet to evaluate the results achieved compared with other institutions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when new outdoor toilets will be provided in Tiernaboul national school in the parish of Killarney, County Kerry; and if she will make a statement on the matter having regard to the fact that the plans are prepared.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department on the recommendations of the Commissioners of Public Works on 16 January 1985 sanctioned a grant towards the cost of providing new toilets in Tiernaboul national school, Killarney, County Kerry. The proposal involved remodelling an existing surplus classroom. The school authorities did not proceed with this work and have since proposed an alternative scheme of outdoor toilets with the object of retaining the classroom in question to meet increases which they believe will occur in pupil enrolments. My Department's local inspector has been asked as a matter of urgency to investigate the position and a decision will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L.T. Cosgrave Mr. L.T. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will consider allocating a grant to a school (details supplied) in Dún Laoghaire, County Dublin, which incurred a large expense, including VAT, on repairs recently; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the secondary schools' building grant scheme, capital grants are not payable towards the cost of maintenance and repairs of schools. That scheme of grants relates to the provision of new school accommodation and extensions to existing accommodation. The annual capitation grants which are paid to schools are intended to meet, inter alia, general maintenance costs including repairs to buildings.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if severely mentally handicapped children who are cared for by their parents at home are entitled to free school transport to enable them to avail of training facilities and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department's authority for operating school transport is limited to conveying pupils to schools recognised by my Department. Transport of severely mentally handicapped children to residential or day care centres where training facilities are available and which are grant assisted by health boards and the Department of Health is a matter for the Minister for Health.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community Youth Training Programme.

Speaker.hpid: Miss M. Barry Miss M. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is satisfied with the speed of administration of the community youth training programme in Cork city and county and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Miss M. Barry Miss M. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is satisfied with the Projects Approval Committee in Cork city and county; and if he agrees that decisions of the committee should be reached by a majority decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 569 and 570 together.
I am satisfied that the difficulties which caused delays in approving projects under the community youth training programme in the Cork area have been overcome.

The support of the social partners has contributed greatly to the success of the programme over the years and I am satisfied that a consensus approach to project approval is the best way of proceeding.
